1.content:
My name is Ramon Martinez, but everyone pretty much calls me Ray. I’m an 18-year-old boy living in a small Massachusetts town with my mother Lucy and 11-year-old sister Isabelle. I have an amazing girlfriend named Kelly; we’ve been dating since our sophomore year of high school. I graduated last year but unfortunately couldn’t go off to college; you see, a botched operation left my mother with constant back pain – this left her unable to work, so I became the sole breadwinner for my family. Where’s my dad you ask? He ran off on us about 6 years ago; no one’s seen or heard from him since.

You’re probably wondering why I’m telling you all this. It’s because my entire life changed in an instant following a car accident on my way home from work. How did it change? I somehow ended up in the body of a pregnant woman in her late 20s.

What follows is my story...
1.title: The Beginning

11.content:
It was just after 4:00 in the afternoon and I was just getting off my third straight 12-hour shift at Wal-Mart; where I worked as an associate in the Electronics Department. The job sucked but the pay was just good enough to support my mom and sister.

Having just clocked out, I was walking to my car when I heard my cell phone start ring. Digging it out of my pocket, I saw it was Kelly calling. Answering the phone, I said, “Hey Kel, what’s up?”

“Not much, babe; I was wondering if you were free tonight.” Chuckling, Kelly said, “I figured you’d want to unwind after working those crazy hours.”

“That sounds like a great idea.” Checking my watch, I said, “But first I have to pick up Isabelle from softball practice. I can be over there around 5:15 if that’s okay.”

“I suppose I can wait until then.” Pausing, Kelly said, “I’ll see you later, babe.”

After hanging up the phone, I continued the walk to my car; a light drizzle starting to fall on the parking lot. I fumbled with my keys for a moment as the rain started to come down even harder. Great, that’s going to make driving on the highway a bear. Finally getting into my car, I sent a quick text to Isabelle to let her know I was coming; before starting the car and driving out of the parking lot.

The drive to the highway was uneventful, save for the annoying squeaking noise that told me I needed to replace my wiper blades. I drove onto the highway without a problem, my GPS telling me it would be about 15 minutes before I got to the exit I needed.
I was driving along, minding my own business and being careful due to the weather when I suddenly heard a screeching noise behind me. I looked over my shoulder to find a large SUV swerving all over the road; it didn’t take a genius to know they were hydroplaning. I tried to avoid the SUV, but it suddenly sideswiped me; which cause me to swerve into the next lane and hit another car.

I was powerless to do anything as both the other car and I were slammed against the median in the center of the highway. The last thing I remembered before blacking out was the panicked look of the woman in the car I’d hit.

****************************


I had no idea how long I’d been unconscious for; but as I regained consciousness, I slowly became aware of my surroundings. Looking around, I quickly realized that I was in a hospital room; and, judging from the window, it was night time. I didn’t pay much attention to the plethora of strange sensations I was suddenly feeling; figuring that it was because of the accident.

I soon became aware of someone else in the room; spotting a man, in his early 30s, dozing in a nearby chair. I didn’t recognize him at all; which made me wonder why he was in my room. Feeling rather weak, I barely had the strength to say, “Hello?”

I thought something was wrong with my voice; but, before I could process it, the man woke up and looked at me. A look of relief on his face, he got up and walked towards me. Taking my hand in his, he said, “Thank god you’re alright, I was so worried.”

Before I could ask who he was, the man leaned over and kissed me on the lips. I found myself reciprocating the kiss for a fraction of a second before I realized what was going on. Shoving the man off of me, I looked at him and said, “What the hell are you doing?”

“Honey, are you alright?” Taking my hand, he said, “It’s me Archie, your husband.”

Husband? I looked at the man, trying to figure out if he was crazy and someone I should be worried about. Looking around the room, I started to wonder where my mom and sister were. Pulling my hand back, I looked at the man and said, “Listen, pal, I’ve never seen you before in my life.”

“Marcie, please...”

I climbed out of the bed before the man could finish his sentence; leaving him speechless as I made my way out the door. Walking out into the hallway, I started to feel my legs give out; stumbling a few times as I made my way down the hall. I have to find my family. The man must’ve gotten some help, because I heard a woman’s voice behind me say, “Ma’am, stop!”
Ma’am? What the hell is going on here?

My leg strength came back as I rounded the corner into what I figured was the Emergency Room. I heard footsteps behind me, so I turned around to find the man and a nurse running down the hall towards me. I have to get out of here. I made a beeline for the exit as the two started to catch up to me. All eyes were on me at this point; as various hospital employees, and some visitors tried to get in my way.

My attempts to reach the door were futile as hospital security had arrived and grabbed me. I struggled to break free from their grip but found that I was somehow weaker than before. “Let go of me! I have to find my family!”

As if on cue, the man appeared in front of me and said, “Marcie, everything’s going to be alright; my mother’s on her way here with Emma as we speak.”

“Why are you calling me Marcie?”

While all this was happening, I became aware of an ambulance arriving outside. The guards moved me to the side as the paramedics came in with a gurney. Nothing could describe the shock I experienced when I saw my body strapped to the gurney as it rolled past; covered in bloody gauze and a large gash down my leg. I watched, in stunned silence, as my family ran past me.
Looking at me, the man said, “Marcie, sweetheart, you have to calm down or the doctors are going to sedate you.”

I was powerless as the guards started to drag me back down the hall; my kicking and screaming weren’t having any effect. Suddenly something out of the corner of my eye; I turned to find myself looking at the reflective surface of a nearby vending machine. What caught my eye wasn’t that the machine had my favorite soda; no, what caught my eye was the reflection of a woman staring back at me.
11.title: The Day My Life Changed

111.content:
After my failed escape attempt, I wasn’t surprised when the guards cuffed me to the bed. I honestly wasn’t paying much attention at that point, as I was trying to wrap my head around the fact that I suddenly looked like a woman. A glance downward proved that what I’d seen hadn’t been an illusion; as I saw a pair of, what was obviously, breasts underneath the hospital gown. What the hell is going on here!?

I was trying to wrap my head around everything that’d happened when the man walked in with a doctor. As the doctor closed the door, the man said, “Is my wife alright, Doctor?” glancing at me, the man said, “I’ve never seen her act that way before.”

“It’s not uncommon for the victims of car accidents to wake up confused.” Looking at a clipboard, the Doctor said, “However, I’ve never seen someone react as your wife did.”

“I don’t know what’s going on here, but I’ve never seen this man before in my life.” Looking at the two of them, I said, “Can one of you please explain how I ended up as a woman?”

Both the man and the doctor looked at me like I was crazy. After a few seconds of silence, the Doctor said, “What do you mean?” confused, he said, “Haven’t you always been a woman?”

I tried my best to respond politely but still managed to come off as dumbfounded. “No, I haven’t always been a woman.” Incredulous, I said, “I used to be an 18-year-old boy until I got into a car accident.”

Unsure how to respond to that, the doctor and the man turned to face away from me. They weren’t whispering, so I managed to hear what they were saying. “Doctor, why does my wife think she’s an 18-year-old boy?”

“My best guess would be that the accident caused some mild disorientation.” Pausing, the doctor said, “There was an 18-year-old boy involved in the accident, but _____.”
111.title: Back In the Room

1111.content:
Surgery? “You’ve got to help me, doc.” Looking at him, with pleading eyes, I said, “My mom. My sister. They depend on me.”

“Is there anything we can do for her, Doctor?” the man called Archie looked at me and said, “She’s nearly got me ready to believe her."

“Sometimes injuries can cause the brain to swell; which can result in temporary amnesia.” Looking at me, he said, “Perhaps that’s what is happening with your wife; although I’m at a loss to explain why she thinks she’s an 18-year-old boy.”

I am an 18-year-old boy, doctor. It was becoming clear that neither Archie nor the doctor believed me; at best they thought I had amnesia, at worst they probably thought I’d gone crazy. Taking my hand in his, Archie said, “Is there anything you can give her to help her sleep until she recovers?”

“There are some medications we could try, but I don’t dare risk it in this case.” With a sigh, the doctor said, “I’m afraid the medications might harm the baby.”

Baby!? That was the last thing I remembered before passing out in shock.

******************************


When I woke up again, I realized I wasn’t in the same room as earlier; this one was slightly smaller, probably one of the hospital’s private rooms. I turned and saw light pouring in through the window on my right. I heard some light snoring to my left and turned to find Archie sleeping in the chair; the poor guy must’ve stayed with the entire night. I probably would have thought the gesture was romantic if I were really the woman he thought I was. I also noticed the doctor standing nearby with his back to me. Archie must’ve sensed that I was awake because he opened his eyes and said, “Marcie?”

I had no idea how I’d ended up in this woman’s body, but I couldn’t honestly say that I was her – regardless of whether there was a baby involved. Looking at him, I silently shook my head.

Walking over from the counter, the Doctor checked my reflexes and vitals before saying, “Perhaps we can shock her back to reality, Mr. Sullivan.” Writing something on the chart, he said, “The young man from the accident was just moved to the recovery room upstairs; they had to remove his appendix, but he came through with flying colors. Hopefully your wife will snap back to reality when he wakes up and proves that she isn’t him.”

With that the doctor left and came back with a wheelchair. Archie helped me into it and I was pushed through the hospital to the recovery room. As we got closer, I could hear Mom and Izzy talking inside. “I think he's starting to wake up, Mom.”

Pushing me to the door, leaning next to my ear, Archie said, “Now you’ll see, Marcie...”

I heard my own voice groan, followed by it saying, “Archie?... Is the baby okay?”
1111.title: He's in surgery

11111.content:
Marcie handled finding herself in my body about as well as I'd handled finding myself in hers. But this 18-year-old boy wasn't pregnant, so they had no problem sedating him. Once Marcie was down, the doctor turned to me and said, "I'm sorry, Ramon."

I waved my hand. "I suppose, if it hadn't happened to me, I'd have found it pretty hard to believe, too."

"What do we do now?" Archie asked.

"Good question," I said. "I don't know how to be a white woman. What do I do, besides ask to speak to the manager, and call the police when I see someone who looks like me in the neighborhood?"

******************************


Eventually, it was decided that I should wait in the room with Marcie until she woke up. When she did, she took one look at me, and said, "Oh, crap, it's real."

"Afraid so," I said. "We might as well find out about each other, since we seem to be stuck like this."

"Fair enough. What do you need to know?"

"I know there's Archie, and the doctor told me I'm pregnant. Any more surprises?"

"Emma. She's super-excited to be a big sister, and she was difficult to keep up with even before I got pregnant. Who will I be dealing with?"

"My mom, and my kid sister, Izzy. How far along am I?"

"Two months. You mentioned your mom and your sister. Where's your father?"

"Tell me, and we'll both know. He ran off years ago. My mom got hurt real bad, so now I've got to support the familia."

We went back and forth like that, each telling the other something, when the doctor came in. "We think we've figured out what happened."
11111.title: Right People, Wrong Bodies

111111.content:
I had just finished telling Marcie about my relationship with Kelly when I suddenly felt an intense pain in my head. As I brought a
hand up, I saw Marcie do the same. I began to scream in pain until everything went black...

When I came too again, I found myself lying on the bed. As my vision returned I saw Marcie’s body in the wheelchair. A quick glance downward revealed no breasts underneath my hospital gown; a fact which a small part of me was disappointed about.
When Marcie started to regain consciousness, I turned to her and said, “Marcie, are you alright?”

“Ramon?” confused, she opened her eyes and said, “A-Are we back in our own bodies?”

“I think so.” Confused, I said, “What happened?”

“I-I don’t know; one minute you were talking about Kelly, the next I felt this incredible pain in my head.”

“The same thing happened to me.” Pausing, I said, “One minute I’m talking to you; then next minute I’m back in my own body.”

Before we could process that any further, Archie and my Mom came running into the room with the Doctor. Looking at me, Mom said, “Ramon, is that you?”

“Yeah.” Confused, I said, “How’d you know?”

“It seems the accident caused the two of you to become connected to each other.” Looking at Marcie and me, the Doctor said, “While you’re both back in your rightful bodies now, I don’t think it’s going to last.”

“What do you mean?” glancing at me, Marcie said, “Are you saying we’re going to keep switching bodies?”

“I’m just a trauma surgeon, so I really have no idea.” Pausing, the Doctor said, “The swaps could only last a few days, or the frequency of the swaps will increase until...”

Marcie and I didn’t like the way the Doctor ended that sentence. Looking at him, I said, “Until what, Doctor?”

“Until the two of you swap bodies with each other permanently.”
111111.title: Something Happened

11112.content:
I opened my eyes who knows how much later. The man - Archie - was there. "Did... did they... ?"

He nodded. "They had to put you under for the MRI. Don't worry, they assured me the baby wouldn't be hurt. The sedative was just to keep you under control. They didn't want you doing anything to hurt the baby, either."

I sighed. I was still stuck in a body that wasn't mine, a life that wasn't mine. "Did the MRI show... ?"

"You have a slight concussion. Other than that, you're perfectly fine. They'll keep you for observation for a few days, just to be sure." He paused. "Do you still think you're this Ramon boy?"

"Yes." My eyes were welling up, and I did nothing to hold back the tears. "What is wrong with me? Either I've gone crazy, or I'm a teenage boy in the body of your wife. God help me, I don't know which is scarier."

Archie patted me on the shoulder. "You'll be okay, Marcie. I'll pull you through this." He still insisted I was his wife. And, frankly, who could blame him? What did I have to prove I was in the wrong body? I wish I was his wife, I thought, then the world would make sense again.

As I began wiping the tears from my eyes, a doctor entered my room. "Mr. Mitchell?"

Archie looked up. "Yes, Doctor?"

"We have an... unusual situation on our hands," the doctor said, "one I feel that the two of you need to be told about. The Martinez boy is out of surgery. He's conscious. And he... he seems to be asking for you."
11112.title: Later On

111121.content:
I insisted on going along when Archie went to see my body with his wife's mind. It took a while to get to the right room, because they insisted I use a walker. Okay, maybe I was a little woozy from the sedative.

Archie walked into the room first, and it was weird to hear my own voice coming from someone else. "Archie," my body said, "you've got to believe it's me! I don't know how this happened! I know how crazy this sounds, but I really am your wife!"

"If you think that sounds crazy," I said, stepping into the room, "wait until you hear this."

My own body pointed at me. "You're... you're the one who's supposed to be in this body?"

I nodded, and placed a hand on my flat belly. "And you're the one who conceived this baby."

"How did this happen?"

"I haven't got a clue." I walked to her bed and sat down. "I've been dealing with this all alone for hours. I was scared that maybe I was just crazy. I don't know how it happened, but neither of us is dealing with it alone anymore."

Hugging yourself is supposed to be lame, but Marcie and I felt better as we embraced.
111121.title: Two People, Two Bodies

1113.content:
The shock from inexplicably finding that I was in a woman’s body, coupled with the knowledge that my body was dead, was too much for me to handle. I started screaming and struggling to break free of the restraints holding me to the bed. This only served to worry the man as he watched me have a mental breakdown.

“What’s wrong with my wife, doctor?” pointing to me, he said, “How could a car accident do this to her?”

“I’m as confused as you are, Mr. Sullivan; I’ve never seen a reaction like this.” Pressing a page button on the wall, the Doctor said, “Is there any history of mental illness in your wife’s family?”

While I was still struggling on the bed, the man said, “Other than some depression and anxiety, there’s nothing like this.” Glancing at me, the man said to the doctor, “Could this be a complication from the pregnancy?”

I immediately stopped what I was doing when I heard that; as preposterous as it sounded, I was apparently pregnant. Looking at the man, I said, “Please just let me go, I’m not your wife.”

A nurse arrived at that moment with what looked like a syringe in her hands. Taking it from the nurse, the doctor said, “Mrs.
Sullivan, I’m going to give you something that should help calm you down. Don’t worry, there’s no risk to the baby.”

The nurse restrained me while the doctor injected me with the syringe. The last thing I remembered before losing consciousness was the man looking at me. “Everything’s going to be alright, honey.”

************************


When I woke up again, I found myself in a completely different room; this one rather spartan in comparison to the one from earlier. With the exception of a bed, a table and a chair, there was almost nothing else in the room. I saw a door leading to a bathroom nearby, which gave me an idea.

I was still coming off whatever the doctor had injected me with, so I stumbled a few times as I went into the bathroom. I closed the door and immediately felt a wave of nausea. Once I stopped vomiting, I got up and stood in front of the mirror.

This was the first opportunity I had to get a good look at this woman’s body...my body. She looked rather attractive; with brown hair and a smattering of freckles on her face. I tried to convince myself that I wasn’t really in this woman’s body, but that was difficult when the reflection in the mirror followed my every move.

I wasn’t ready to do so, but I decided to get it over with – I looked under the hospital gown to find a pair of nice, slightly larger than normal, breasts. This has to be a dream. I stared at my reflection for another minute or so as I tried to figure out my next move. After composing myself the best I could, I turned and walked out of the bathroom; only to find an African-American woman, in her mid to late 20s, leaning against the wall wearing scrubs.

I hadn’t heard anyone come in while I was in the bathroom, so I was surprised to see her standing there. Looking at her, I said, “Can I help you?”

“I’ve been doing this a very long time; but I must say, I’ve never seen anyone react quite like you.”

I sat down on the bed, confused. Looking at her, I said, “What do you mean?”

“Most people in your position are initially shocked; but to see you have a complete breakdown, that wasn’t what I expected.”

I thought she was referring to the accident, so I looked at her and said, “It’s not every day you find yourself in a woman’s body after a car accident.”

I was surprised that, unlike the man and the doctor, the nurse didn't seem phased when I implied that I hadn't always been a woman. “I would try to keep to that to yourself if I were you. Right now you're only a temporary patient in the hospital's psych ward; but if you kept it up, you'll be committed to a mental hospital.” Looking at me, as I lay back on the bed, she said, “I’ll come back to check on you later; after you’ve had some time to process everything.”

I closed my eyes briefly as the woman headed towards the door; when I opened them again she was gone. I was lying on the bed, a moment later, when the door opened; a pregnant nurse walked into the room. “Hello Mrs. Sullivan, how are you feeling today?”

“I guess I’m feeling pretty good; despite suddenly becoming a woman.” Watching as the nurse checked my blood pressure, I said, “Why couldn’t the nurse who was just in here check my blood pressure?”

“Excuse me?”

“The African-American woman, probably a few years older than you; why couldn’t she check my blood pressure?”

The nurse gave me the same look the doctor and the man had given me; like I was crazy. Looking at me, with a nervous chuckle, she said, “Ma’am, we don’t have any African-American nurses on this shift.”

Hearing that, I started to wonder if I was going crazy. I remembered talking to the woman before she left, but apparently she didn’t exist. If I was imagining that, what if I was imagining everything else as well – what if I really was that man’s wife.

Before I could respond to the nurse, as if on cue, the door opened; and the man walked into the room carrying a little girl in his arms. “Emma, sweetie, say hi to Mommy.”
1113.title: He's Dead

11131.content:
I was lying on the bed, facing the man and the nurse, when the bundle of energy known as Emma ran over to me. She climbed up on the bed, with help from the nurse, and embraced me. “Are you feeling better, Mommy?”

I’m not your mom, kid. Despite everything that I was going through, I didn’t have it in me to take it out on this little girl. In addition to not fully understanding how I’d ended up in this woman’s body, I still had no idea what had happened to the original occupant. I wasn’t about to devastate this little girl by saying I wasn’t her mother. “I’m feeling fine, sweetie; mommy just needs to rest a few days.” Reflexively pulling her closer, I said, “Can you promise to be a good girl for daddy while I’m away?”

“Uh-huh!” leaning over to kiss me on the cheek, Emma said, “Feel better mommy.”

I leaned over and kissed her on the forehead, “Thank you, sweetie.”

After the nurse left the room with Emma, the man closed the door and came over to my bed. “I’m sorry it’s come to this, honey; but I just want to make sure you’re okay.”

So you’re the reason I’m in the psych ward. As I sat on the bed, looking at him, I realized I couldn’t really blame him for this. After all, as hard as it was for me to believe, I did look like this man’s wife – a wife he thought was having a mental breakdown. Deep down I knew I was Ramon; but if I wanted to keep from getting committed, I had to play along. “It’s alright, Archie; you’re doing what you think is best.”

“It’s only a 72 hour psychiatric hold; so you’ll be out of here in no time.” Sitting down next me to, Archie took my hand and said, “Emma and I will be here, waiting, when you get out.”

The feeling of Archie’s hand on mine had an unexpected affect on me; I felt like I was being pulled in different directions at once. As I looked into Archie’s concerned eyes, I was overcome with foreign feelings. Before I knew what was happening, I leaned
forward and kissed Archie on the lips.

As he started to reciprocate, Archie and I lay back on the bed as we kissed. I was completely aware of what I was doing; I knew it wasn’t right, but I couldn’t stop myself. This isn’t right, I have to focus. I’m not this man’s wife, I’m a boy. I reflexively let out a soft moan between kisses. Wasn't I?

As the two of us made out on the hospital bed, I found it harder and harder to think straight. Don’t be silly Ramon, of course you’re a boy.

Before Archie and I could go further, there was a knock on the door. We pulled apart as the door opened; revealing the pregnant nurse from earlier. She must’ve realized what we were doing, because she blushed and said, “I wasn’t interrupting anything, was I?”

“No ma’am, you weren’t.” blushing, moving a strand of hair, I said, “I was just having a moment with my husband before he left.”

“I’m sorry, Mrs. Sullivan, but it’s time for your first appointment with Dr. Stewart.”

“Okay.” Getting up, I took one last look at Archie and said, “I’ll see you tomorrow, honey.”

After saying goodbye to Archie, I followed the nurse out of the room. As we made our way down the hall, I found myself thinking back to the kiss. I haven’t felt that way since the first time I kissed Kelly. Feeling a sudden ache in my head, I brought a hand up to rub my temple. That’s weird; I’ve never kissed a girl before.
11131.title: Questioning Reality

111311.content:
The nurse and I walked through the halls of the psych ward; past rooms that contained patients with worse issues than me. I had to remind myself that I was only here temporarily because my husband was worried about me. As I walked through the halls, I found myself second-guessing myself – mainly my relationship with Archie. I was his wife, wasn’t I?

As we rounded the corner, I saw the woman from earlier standing across from an open door. Looking at me, she said, “This isn’t a good idea, Ramon; you don’t know what’s at stake here.”

Ignoring the woman, I followed the nurse through the doorway – labeled Dr. Rachel Stewart, MD. Dr. Stewart looked to be around my age; a little heavyset but still attractive. As I sat down on the couch, I saw the woman walk into the room and stand by the door; a look of concern on her face.

After the nurse left, Dr. Stewart closed the door and sat across from me. “Hello Mrs. Sullivan, I’m Rachel.”

“Please, call me Marcie.”

“Of course.” Smiling, she looked at me and said, “Now Marcie, do you know why you’re here?”

“I was in a car accident where a young man was killed.” Sighing, with a faint smile, I said, “After I woke up, I was under the belief that I was that young man; that I’d somehow been placed in this body.”

“I believe you’re referring to reincarnation?” writing something on a notepad, Dr. Stewart said, “You believed that you were that young man; that you were reincarnated as Marcie Sullivan?”

The woman, still standing by the doorway, just stared at me; it was clear she was worried about something. “I’m not sure what I believed at the time; but I was adamant that I wasn’t the woman they told me I was.”

“Do you still believe that now?”

I’m not sure, Doctor. “No ma’am, I’m no longer under the impression that I was that poor young man.” Smiling, I said, “My husband, and the ER doctor, believed that I in a state of shock.”

“It’s common, in accidents such as yours, for victims to have memory loss.” Looking at her pad, Dr. Stewart said, “Do you know your daughter’s name?”

“Emma.”

With an affirmative nod, Dr. Stewart continued, “Do you remember when she was born?”

I tried my best to find the answer to that question but was unable to do so. I started to get a little emotional as a result. “I-I don’t remember.” Tearing up, I said, “What kind of mother doesn’t remember when her daughter was born?”

“I’m sorry for upsetting you, Marcie.” Placing her hand on mine, Dr. Stewart says, “From what I’ve been told, you’re an amazing mother. With time I’m certain you’ll regain your memories.”

The woman in the corner moved until she was standing next to Dr. Stewart. Looking at me, she said, “Ramon, you have to fight this. You know who you are!”

“I’m Marcie Sullivan!”
Dr. Stewart was taken aback by my sudden outburst. Looking at me, she said, “Marcie, are you alright?”

“No, I’m not fine.” Pointing to the woman next to her, I said, “That nurse keeps telling me that I’m that young man.”

Dr. Stewart turned to look where I was pointing; I was certain she would yell at the nurse. Instead, she looked back at me and said, “Marcie, there’s no one in here but us.”
111311.title: The Counseling Session, Pt 1.

1113111.content:
I was dumbfounded as I stared at Dr. Stewart; she had to be joking around. Looking at her, I said, “I may have mistakenly believed I was that poor young man, but I can assure you that there’s a woman standing right next to you.”

The woman just placed a hand on her forehead and shook her head in disbelief. Meanwhile, Dr. Stewart looked at me and said, “I assure you, Marcie; there’s no one else in this room.” pausing, she said, “I wouldn’t let anyone, even a nurse, sit in on these sessions.”

I could see the look on Dr. Stewart’s face; I knew what she was thinking. “I’m not crazy, Dr. Stewart.”

“I never said you were, Marcie.” Leaning forward, Dr. Stewart said, “I’m just concerned there might be an underlying issue here.”
My God, this woman thinks I’m crazy. “There’s no underlying issue here; my husband said there’s no history of mental illness in my family.”

While this was going on, the woman walked over and knelt down next to me. Looking at me, concern in her voice, she said, “Ramon, you’re heading down a dangerous path here.” Sighing, she said, “You have to snap out of this before its too late.”

Dr. Stewart looked at me and saw that I was staring off to my right; even though there was nothing there. “Is she standing on your right, Marcie?”

“Yes.” Looking at Dr. Stewart, I said, “She’s calling me Ramon and saying I’m heading down a dangerous path.”

“What does this woman look like, Marcie?” grabbing her tablet, jotting down some notes, Dr. Stewart said, “Have you seen her before?”

“She’s African-American, probably around my height and age; I’ve never seen her before in my life.” Starting to get worried, I said, “Am I going insane, Doctor?”

“I don’t want to jump the gun here, Marcie.” Grabbing her prescription pad, Dr. Stewart said, “I’m going to write you a prescription for some sedatives; so you can relax a little.”

“T-Thank you.”

The nurse from before came in a few minutes later; this time to bring me back to the room. I was keenly aware of the fact that the woman was following me. I glanced over my shoulders a few times to find her walking behind me. Whispering under my breath, I said, “Go away, you’re not real.”

“You have to listen to me, Ramon; you don’t have a lot of time.”

I’d arrived back at my room at that point; walking inside to sit on the bed. Looking at me, the nurse said, “I’ll be back for you in a little while, Mrs. Sullivan.”

Lying on the bed, I said, “Thank you.”

Once the nurse left, the woman said, “You really need to listen to me, Ramon.”

“Stop it!” closing my eyes, I placed my hands over my ears and said, “You’re not real!”
1113111.title: The Counseling Session, Pt 2

11131111.content:
Despite all my best attempts, I couldn’t ignore the ‘woman’ as she spent the next 20 minutes trying to get me to either look at her or listen to her. “Ramon if you don’t snap out of it soon, you’ll never regain your memories.”

That part had gotten my attention; leading me to think back to how I couldn’t remember Emma’s birthday. Am I a terrible mother? I knew there was a camera in the room, for security purposes; I knew it was recording everything but I didn’t care. Sitting up in bed, I looked at the ‘woman’ and said, “Are you saying that if I accept that I’m really that deceased boy, that I’ll get my memories back?” pausing, I said, “That I’ll remember marrying Archie and giving birth to Emma?”

“What?” looking at me, the ‘woman’ said, “No, you’ll remember your life as Ramon; your mom, your sister and your girlfriend.”

Why would I want to remember a ‘life’ with a family I’ve never met?” getting up, I started pacing around the bed. Looking at the ‘woman’, I said, “Why am I even arguing with you? You’re not even real.”

The ‘woman’ was starting to get flustered; her face turning red and looking as though she was going to start yelling. After a moment, however, she calmly looked at me and said, “I am real, Ramon; the sooner you accept that the better off you’ll be.”

“You are not real.” Turning to look at her, I said, “My husband is real, my daughter is real. The baby growing inside me is real. You are not real.”

As I turned to look away from her, the ‘woman’ said, “I’m just trying to help you Ramon; believe me, you don’t want to know what’s coming.”

“If you really wanted to help me, then just leave me alone.” Placing my arms across my chest, I turned around and said, “The longer you’re here bothering me, the longer I’ll be kept from my family.”

“Your fam...” I could tell the woman wanted to say something else, but she stopped. “Fine, since you’re being incredibly stubborn, I’ll just leave. When you’re ready to listen to me, I hope it’s not too late.”

I watched, with a satisfied smile, as the ‘woman’ simply disappeared from the room. I sat down on the bed, feeling triumphant, as
the nurse walked into the room. “Mrs. Sullivan, how would you like to see the rec room?”

“I’d like that very much.” Pausing, I said, “I need a change of scenery.”
11131111.title: Ramon's Stubborness

111311111.content:
The rec room was actually bigger than I thought it was; given how small the hospital’s psych ward was. I walked inside to find it empty – save for a young woman sitting on a nearby couch reading a book. I glanced at her as I walked past; seeing that she looked to be only a few years younger than me.

After grabbing a book from the shelf, I turned back and walked towards the couch. Looking at the young woman, engrossed in her book, I said, “I’m sorry to interrupt, but I was wondering if I could join you.”

“Huh?” looking up, she saw me standing there. Pulling her legs back, she said, “Sorry, have a seat.”

As I sat down, I opened the book briefly before putting it down. Turning my attention to the young woman, I said, “My name’s Marcie Sullivan.”

I got the sense the young woman wanted to be left alone, but she decided to be polite instead. “Allison Young.” Putting her book down, she said, “What are you in for?”

“I was in a car accident that messed me up pretty badly.” Sighing, I said, “I can’t remember anything about my family, and I’m seeing people that aren’t really there.”

“I wish I was in here for something as simple as that.” Looking at me, Allison said, “I’m here for suicide watch.”

I didn’t want to pry, but a part of me was curious. Looking at Allison, I said, “If you don’t mind my asking, why are you on suicide watch?”

“I tried killing myself after my ex-boyfriend posted some revenge porn online.”

My maternal instincts began to kick in at that point. “I-I’m sorry to hear that.”

Allison then proceeded to tell me everything that happened; both leading up to her breakup and the revenge porn. When she was finished, holding back tears, she said, “You want to know the worst part of all this? My parents believe I’m a lesbian now; because they saw a video of me making out with my female roommate at a party.” With a weak smile, Allison chuckled and said, “Now they want nothing to do with me because I’m a ‘freak.’ The worst part is, I think they’re trying to turn my younger sisters against me.”

Suddenly my issues didn’t seem so bad in comparison. “How did that lead to the suicide watch?”

“I tried to OD on sleeping pills after a particularly bad telephone call.” Moving some hair from her eyes, Allison said, “I probably would have died had my roommate not found me. She was concerned for my safety and convinced me to come here.”

I sat there, silently, as I watched Allison start crying uncontrollably. Despite having just met her, I couldn’t help but feel sorry for her. I moved over and pulled Allison into a hug; letting her cry into my arms. Rubbing my arm on her back, in a soothing tone, I said, “Just cry it out, Allison; everything will be alright.”
111311111.title: The Rec Room

1113111111.content:
As Allison got it out of her system, she said, "You must think I'm weird, going on and doing this to somebody who I just met."

"I think you needed this," I replied. "I walked in, I didn't want anything from you, I just wanted to know how you were doing. From the sound of it, you weren't getting that."

About then, the psychiatrist came in. "Excellent," she said. "I like to see my patients helping each other. My name is Dr. Mixter. Shall we begin?"

Allison and I sat down with Dr. Mixter.

"Who would like to start?" Dr. Mixter asked.

"I will," I said. "It occurred to me that, if I ignore these false memories I have, I can make room for my real memories to come back. I've also started ignoring my hallucinations."

"And how is that working for you?"

"My memories haven't come back yet, but the woman I was hallucinating said she was going to leave me alone."

"Sounds good. Allison?"

"I don't have a story for you, or any special insights. Maybe tomorrow."

Dr. Mixter smiled. "Hearing you use that word gives me hope. How about you?"

It dawned on Allison. "I made a plan, didn't I?"

"Yes , you did. How does that make you feel?"

She thought for a moment. "I like the word."
1113111111.title: Female Bonding

choices: I switch back into my body again.
112.content:
I felt as if I were going to faint, in fact, I did. I felt myself falling... only I did not feel myself hit the floor or hear the sounds of the man or woman behind me. I instead heard the beep beep beep of some machine in the room. I could not have been the vending machine it had to have been something else. As I found the ability to open my eyes, I found myself lying in a hospital bed with my parents and my sister, Isabelle looking over me with tear stained faces. I heard them all gasp as I caught their eyes before they began to laugh and cry at the same time.

"He's awake!" Crying, mom declared. "I'll get the nurse!"

"Don't scare us like that again." pouting, Isabelle scolded. "We thought you had died!"

"You did give us a big scare, son." Smiling, dad said. "I'm just glad that you are okay."

I was about to respond when I heard a woman's vice in the hall. In fact, it was the voice i had heard myself use only moments earlier... "I don't know what happened, Archie." Sounding confused, the woman said. "For a moment there, I did not recognize anyone or anything..."

"Don't worry about it, my sweet." Cooing, Archie said. "The important thing is that you remember now and we can work on getting you and our child better."

"Was I just in her body...?" Startled, I thought. "How is that even possible...?"

Then, I felt myself become dizzy again as if I were about to faint. In the next breath, I was back inside the woman, Marcie with Archie and the nurse keeping me from falling. "We better get your wife back into bed." Firmly, the nurse said.

"Wait, please, Archie." Weakly, I said. "That poor boy..."

Archie and the nurse turned to see my body in the room next to us, staring in shock. "You know him, Marcie?" curious, Archie asked.

I nodded. "He's the boy who was in the other car..."
112.title: A Mind Hopping Problem.

choices: I get a crash corse in soul hopping.
I find myself in anther person.
1122.content:
I felt faint once again and found myself back inside my body. For a brief moment, Marcie and I stared at each other before I turned to her husband. "Archie... we have a real big conundrum on our hands."

Archie looked at me, his eyes growing wide. "I have only heard Marcie say that to me." Surprised, he said. "Do we know you..."

"Honey... I know this seems impossible but, we had swapped bodies for awhile there."

"You... what...?!" Confused, Archie demanded. "That is just not possible."

Dad sighed. "I'm afraid it is possible." Darkly, he said. "You see... I'm a meta-human."

The color began to drain from Archie's face. "Why is this happening?"

"What is a meta-human?" Confused, Marcie asked.

Mom sighed herself and pulled up a comfortable chair for Marcie to sit in which she accepted then asked the nurse to get one for Archie. "A meta-human is a human born with more than ten percent of their brain's potential unlocked." Serious, she explained. "In my husband's case, he has the ability to swap souls with another." she giggled slightly. "He experienced the entire nine months and delivery of our daughter, Isabelle."

"Why is your son swapping souls with my wife?" Irritated, Archie demanded.

"I doubt he is doing it deliberately." Serious, dad countered. "My guess is that he saw his life flash before his eyes and it triggered his ability."

"Only now, he is having trouble staying back inside his own body." turning pale, Marcie said. "Is there anything we can do?"

Dad nodded. "Ramon needs to learn how to control his ability otherwise he may end up stuck as your wife for life or worse."

I gulped. "Worse...?"

Again, dad nodded. "You could end up becoming absorbed by Marcie's mind, creating an entirely new personality or the other way around." Darkly, he said. "That or you could end up becoming her unborn child or her unborn child's twin, male or female."

"Oy vey!" Worried, I muttered. "Why me...?"

"We still have time." Serious, dad said. "While I teach my son how to control his newly activated ability, I will need you to do something, Archie."

Archie raised a single eyebrow. "Which is...?"

"You need to keep your wife's mind active." Serious, dad said. "I cannot enter the body of a person whose mind and body is active and distracted."

Archie nodded. "Consider it done."

"I just hope we can train Ramon before he ends up leaping into another person's body and the search has to start all over again." Worried, mom said.
1122.title: Meta-humans

11221.content:
"First and foremost, I am a volunteer life saver." Serious, dad explained. "I swap souls with people, male or female who are having troubles in their relationships whether they be romantic or professional. However, due to the legal and social ramifications I suffered starting the business, I had to led everyone to believe I was dead for a while."

I nodded though I really had not thought about it due to my own situation. "How do you swap souls?" Wincing, I asked.

"The trigger is different for everyone who has the ability." Calmly, dad replied. "Mine is feeling an empathy towards the person I switch with hence I require an interview before I take any action at all."

"What do you think is my trigger is?" Curious, I asked.

"Well, your ability seemed to have been triggered by a near death experience." Musing, mom said. "That said, I would say your trigger is..."

"Empathy for the wounded." Serious dad interrupted. "Look at yourself... not a scratch from the accident but young Marcie sustained a lot of minor injuries."

"Of course..." Softly, mom said. "You're built like a tank, it takes a lot to injure you."

"One of the advantages of being a meta-human." Serious, dad said. "The only reason you had not swapped into another body is because you have not encountered anyone more seriously injured than Marcie."

"So, once she is healed..." hopeful, I said.

"You will likely return to your normal body... in theory." Softly, dad said. "I must say in theory because we do not know all of the factors that went into the first swap."

"So what do I do...?" Wincing, I asked.

Dad sighed. "I know it sounds cruel to both you and Marcie but you have to..."
11221.title: I get a crash corse in soul hopping.

info.brief_description: A young man's life is turned upside after a car accident leaves him in a woman's body.
info.description:
Ramon Martinez was a hard-working 18-year-old man; working to support his mother and little sister. He's on his way to pick up his sister from softball practice when he gets into a car accident on the highway. When he wakes up in the hospital, much to his shock, he finds himself in a woman's body - the one driving the car he'd slammed into.

What follows is his story as he tries to make sense of what happened.

Rules:
1. Use proper grammar
2. Be creative with storylines but keep close to the original idea.
3. Use the 1st person perspective (I, I'll, I'm, etc) - as the story will be from Ramon's POV.
4. I reserve the right to edit, and/or/ remove chapters.
